abstract.text: Overridden by subclasses to draw the view’s image within the specified rectangle.

inlineContent.text: A rectangle defining the portion of the view that requires redrawing. This rectangle usually represents the portion of the view that requires updating. When responsive scrolling is enabled, this rectangle can also represent a nonvisible portion of the view that AppKit wants to cache.
Use this method to draw the specified portion of your view’s content. Your implementation of this method should be as fast as possible and do as little work as possible. The

parameter helps you achieve better performance by specifying the portion of the view that needs to be drawn. You should always limit drawing to the content inside this rectangle. For even better performance, you can call the
method and use the list of rectangles returned by that method to limit drawing even further. You can also use the
method test whether objects in a particular rectangle need to be drawn.

The default implementation does nothing. Subclasses should override this method if they do custom drawing. Prior to calling this method, AppKit creates an appropriate drawing context and configures it for drawing to the view; you do not need to configure the drawing context yourself. If your app manages content using its layer object instead, use the
method to update your layer instead of overriding this method.
If your custom view is a direct
subclass, you do not need to call
at some point in your implementation so that the parent class can perform any additional drawing.
, the view must completely fill the

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
These constants specify the type of a view’s border.
The infrastructure for drawing, printing, and handling events in an app.
Returns a bitmap-representation object suitable for caching the specified portion of the view.
Draws the specified area of the view, and its descendants, into a provided bitmap-representation object.
A Boolean value indicating whether the view can draw its contents on a background thread.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the view, and its subviews, confine their drawing areas to the bounds of the view.
Displays the view and all its subviews if possible, invoking each of the
methods
, and
as necessary.
Overridden by subclasses to draw the view’s image within the specified rectangle.
Returns by indirection a list of nonoverlapping rectangles that define the area the view is being asked to draw in
A Boolean value indicating whether the view uses a flipped coordinate system.
A Boolean value indicating whether the view fills its frame rectangle with opaque content.
Locks the focus on the view, so subsequent commands take effect in the view’s window and coordinate system.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the specified rectangle intersects any part of the area that the view is being asked to draw.
Marks the region of the view within the specified rectangle as needing display, increasing the view’s existing invalid region to include it.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the view is being drawn to an environment that supports color.
Unlocks focus from the current view.
Updates the view’s content by modifying its underlying layer.
The portion of the view that isn’t clipped by its superviews.
A Boolean value indicating whether AppKit’s default clipping behavior is in effect.
A true value.
A rectangle.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
